utterances: WNYC, New York and I'm a member of New York Public Radio.
Thank you so much for playing this week.
So, Will, what's our challenge for next week?
Yes, name a food item.
Divide this word in half.
If you take the second half, followed by the first half twice, you'll get a familiar saying.
And if you take the second half twice, followed by the first half, you'll name a well-known person.
What's the food item and what's the saying and name?
A food item.
Divide this word in half.
Take the second half followed by the first half twice, you'll name a familiar saying.
And take the second half twice, followed by the first half, you'll name a well-known person.
What's the food item and what's the saying and name?
When you have the answer, go to our website, NPR.org/puzzle and click on the Submit Your Answer link - just one entry per person, please.
And because of the Thanksgiving holiday, our deadline for entries this week is Wednesday, November 23rd at 3 P.M. Eastern Time.
Please include a phone number where we can reach you at about that time.
If you're the winner we'll give you a call, and you'll get to play on the air with the puzzle editor of The New York Times and WEEKEND EDITION's puzzle-master, Will Shortz.
Thanks so much, Will.
Thanks, Audie.
For some of us, this time of the year prompts vivid memories of sleep-away camp, some good, some bad, others traumatizing.
We can close our eyes and think fondly of songs around the campfire and capture the flag, the nice kid who made friends, or stupid sports, missing home, and that big, old bully.
What we didn't know at the time was that how much we liked it or hated it would predict what kind of person we'd grow up to be.
Timothy Noah decoded the sleep-away camp experience in a piece for the online magazine Slate, and he joins us in just a moment to explain.
So, whether you loved it or called your parents to come and get you out of there, did summer camp predict your future character?
Our phone number is 800-989-8255.
You can e-mail Camp TOTN at talk@npr.org, and you can join the conversation on our blog at npr.org/blogofthenation.
Timothy Noah is a senior writer at Slate.
His piece is called ""You Are How You Camped,"" and Tim, nice to have you on the program again.
Thanks for having me, Neal.
And you hated camp.
What did that say about you?
I did hate camp.
Well, you know, I disliked camp, I think that's probably fairer to say.
You know, I just wasn't an organized-activities kind of kid, and I sort of hated all of the rituals.
I hated color war, and I particularly didn't like color war because I was put on the opposite team from my older brother, and you know, I was kind of literal-minded about this.
I thought, why am I - you know, why should I be regarding my brother as, you know, the enemy, a black beret, when I am an orange baton?
And I did concede in the piece that this does suggest that I would have made a very bad Kennedy.
(Soundbite of laughter)
I don't really sort of get the touch-football ethic of fierce competitiveness between siblings.
And you conclude that people like yourself, who did not enjoy camp, tend to have problems engaging in organized activities of all kinds, and later in life, we become criminals or sociopaths.
Criminals or sociopaths, well, that's if things go badly, but if things go well, some of us become journalists and...
And what's the difference there?
(Soundbite of laughter)
It's a fine line.
OK.
And you know, if we're extremely bright or creative, we might be writers, scholars or artists.
Now, I concede in my piece that this is a somewhat self-serving argument, but as the author of the piece, I claim that that is my privilege.
And then, you go on to analyze people who had different experiences at summer camp.
You disliked it.
There are people who hated it so much that they called their parents and said, come and get me, take me home!
Right.
And these people are not to be confused with people who didn't like summer camp.
I don't think there is anything outre about not being able to endure summer camp.
I just think it's neurotic and needy.
And so, I think that the people in this category, later in life, are seriously out of sync with the rest of society.
These are the people who will call up C-SPAN's early-morning show, ""Washington Journal,"" and filibuster for 20 minutes without asking a question.
These are people who just cannot handle modern life.
Let's see if we get some callers in on this conversation, 800-989-8255.
Email talk@npr.org.
Chelsea's on the line, Chelsea calling us from Louisville in Kentucky.
Yes.
I was calling to let you know about my experience with summer sleep-away camp.

My daughter, this was her very first year going to sleep-away camp, and I was excited to see how she would react to it, because my sister and I, when we were children, had such different experiences...
And how did you react differently from your sister?
I loved camp, I wanted to stay all summer, and my sister came crying to me every day, begging me to let her go home.
Was she older or younger?
She was younger than I was, and so I don't think I was very compassionate...
(Soundbite of laughter)
Because I was having such a good time, I didn't understand why she wanted to go home.

So, what my comment was, is that I think it was funny that as we grew up, I thought for sure, since I loved to be away from home, that I would be the one that would move several states away from our family, or move to a different country.
And in reality, I'm the one that lives two miles from my parents, and my sister is someone that moved 10 hours away.
There's been a big development in the mysterious death of a Border Patrol agent last November.
He died after being found near a remote highway in West Texas.
President Trump and border wall supporters speculated it was a brutal murder by smugglers.
The FBI now says after an exhaustive investigation, that they have found no evidence the officer's death was a homicide.
NPR's John Burnett reports.
On the moonless night of November 18, the bleeding, battered body of Rogelio Martinez was found at the base of a culvert below Interstate 10.
It was near the town of Van Horn about 130 miles east of El Paso and 30 miles across the rugged desert from the Mexican border.
But was it a crime scene or an accident site?
He and Agent Stephen Garland had been inspecting a drainage area for illegal activity when the incident happened.
Martinez's death fit the narrative the president and border hawks were advancing.
The borderlands are lawless and must be tamed.
Suspicions immediately fell on smugglers or unauthorized immigrants.
Speculation was they wielded rocks to brutally beat the pair.
The Border Patrol closed ranks around this scenario.
That area, Van Horn - you know, those culverts - they're pretty well-known for marijuana smugglers in particular.
That's Victor Manjarrez.
He retired from the Border Patrol after 23 years, including two stints as chief agent in the Southwest.
He's now with The Center for Law & Human Behavior at the University of Texas at El Paso.

But late Wednesday, the FBI in El Paso said after 650 interviews involving 37 field offices, investigators could find no evidence supporting, quote, ""the existence of a scuffle, altercation or attack"" involving the agents.

An autopsy found that Martinez died of severe head trauma, but the FBI said there were no defensive wounds on Martinez or his partner and no third-party blood or DNA evidence recovered from their clothing.
Garland is still recovering from injuries to his back and skull.
He cannot remember what happened that night.
A radio dispatcher recalled a disoriented and wounded Garland telling her, we ran into a culvert, but he didn't say what happened in the culvert.
The FBI investigation remains open and inconclusive, and Manjarrez says the case may take longer to crack.
My 23 years' experience on the Border Patrol tells me there's always evidence.
You just haven't found it.
Victor Manjarrez and many active agents remain convinced it was foul play.
My hunch still tells me that's - it's an assault.
There have been other theories.
A nearby county sheriff who was one of the first responders has speculated the agents may have been sideswiped by an 18-wheeler speeding along the interstate.
But the day after the agent's death, President Trump tweeted, we will seek out and bring to justice those responsible.
We will and must build the wall.
And the smuggler ambush story carried the day.
The FBI put up a reward for $50,000 for resolution of the case and posted the dead agent's photo on billboards from Texas to Southern California.
Texas Senator Ted Cruz tweeted that the death was a stark reminder of the ongoing threat that an unsecure border poses.
A homicide was credible because assaults on border agents jumped nearly 50 percent to 847 assaults last year, a reflection of increased tensions along the international divide.
Carry Huffman is chief of strategic planning at the Border Patrol.
You know, that's an alarming trend that we see.
The border has been and remains a dangerous place.
The FBI says the case of Agent Martinez remains a top priority, and it will continue to pursue all logical leads and investigative avenues.
John Burnett, NPR News.
This is TALK OF THE NATION.
I'm Neal Conan, in Washington.
And here are the headlines from some of the stories we're following here today at NPR News.
An early morning bomb attack devasted a major Shiite shrine in Iraq today, spawning reprisal attacks against dozens of Sunni mosques.
President Bush has urged restraint among rival religious factions, and pledged American help to restore the revered shrine.
And France has denounced the kidnapping, torture, and murder of a young Jewish man in Paris as an anti-semitic crime.
France's interior minister said the killers were primarily motivated by greed, and believe that Jews were wealthy targets.
Details on those stories, and, of course, much more later today on ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
Tomorrow on TALK OF THE NATION, the future of the global economy hinges on two Asian superpowers, China and India.
How they compare, how they compete, and what that means for our future, tomorrow on TALK OF THE NATION.
It's been said that happiness requires a lot more than mere success.
You also have to see your friends fail.
In that regard, I have to tell you that my friend Sarah Dunant has been a real disappointment.

We met in London, where she was a host of the radio show, Woman's Hour, went on to write a series of distressingly good thrillers, and then scored an international success with an historical novel called The Birth of Venus.
Now she's back with another Renaissance romp, titled In The Company of the Courtesan.
It's about a high- class prostitute named Fiammetta, and her partner and pimp, a dwarf named Bucino.
The book opens with the sack of Rome in 1527, and follows our heroes as they struggle to reestablish their business in the magnificent city of Venice.
Sarah Dunant joins us here in Studio 3A, and I'm going to ask you, I'd read a passage from this book for us, but first I have to say, I hate you.
